and I'm just so grateful I raised the

we must keep it up and I think the key

our situation in terms of the spread of

how important it is that we don't slow

the latest analysis of data in England

Alex died in hospital with the
coronavirus ten days ago none of his
family could be with him but staff did
set up a video call and his son says
that made all the difference it felt
like we were together it was really rich
it was really real he was weak but we
also connected as a families often
there'll be three or four of us on the

could speak with each other comfort each
other make plans we felt together which
is I've not really experienced that
before this is what patients will be
aware of around them staff like these at

is difficult that's tough for doctors
and nurses as well as those who they
care for dr. Rachel Clark who
specializes in end-of-life care says it
can be an emotional drain sometimes
you've tried your utmost to be there at
a time when perhaps a loved one a son or
daughter or spouse can't be there and
you're literally all the patient has and
with every fiber of your being all you
want to do is support that patient the
upward trend in deaths appears to be
slowing but whatever the statistics say
there are life and death issues for
thousands of families to confront every
day in every part of the country
